pages.text: An old man wears a royal robe over his armor.$(br)  He has a form of the Ankh for his sceptre and a globe in his left hand. He is a crowned monarch - commanding, stately, seated on a throne.$(br)  He is Execution and Realization, the power of this world, here adorned with the highest of its natural attributes.$(br)  He is the vigorous power, to which $(l:patchouli:major/3the_empress)The Empress$() responds, and in this sense is he who seeks to remove the Veil of

Nature; yet she remains undefiled.$(br)  As $(l:patchouli:major/3the_empress)The Empress$()'s consort, he brings law and human society to her abundant nature; the sign of structured order applied to fertile chaos.$(br)  It should be understood that these couple of cards do not precisely represent a married couple, though this state is implied.$(br)  On the surface, they stand for mundane royalty, uplifted on the seats of the mighty; but above this there is another

meaning: the command of the subtle thrones.$(br)  He is the lordship of thought rather than of feeling.$(br2)$(l)Divinatory meanings$()$(br)  Law, structure, the social order; these may be less powerful than they seem.$(br)  May also mean fatherhood.$(br2)$(l)Reversed$()$(br)  Whatever undermines law and order.$(br)  Discovering who is pulling the strings.
